questions.text: A female with breast cancer undergoes investigation which reveals the presence of ER positivity. Presence of ER is important as it is a:  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Predictive marker

 

Estrogen receptor (ER) positivity in breast cancer is primarily used as a predictive marker. The presence of ER indicates that the cancer cells are likely to respond to hormonal therapies such as tamoxifen or aromatase inhibitors. These therapies work by blocking estrogen receptors or decreasing estrogen levels in the body, which helps slow or stop the growth of ER-positive breast cancer cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diagnostic marker: The presence of ER is not used to diagnose breast cancer, as normal breast tissue can also express estrogen receptors. Therefore, ER positivity alone cannot confirm a diagnosis of breast cancer.

 

Option B. Prognostic marker: While ER status can provide some prognostic information, such as indicating a potentially better outcome due to responsiveness to hormone therapy, it is not solely used for prognosis. Prognostic factors typically include tumor size, lymph node status, and other molecular markers.

 

Option D. Surrogate molecular marker: A surrogate molecular marker is used as a substitute for a clinical endpoint. ER positivity does not serve as a surrogate molecular marker in this context; instead, it directly informs the treatment approach and potential response to therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ER positivity in breast cancer is a predictive marker that helps determine the likelihood of response to hormonal therapies, making it crucial for guiding treatment decisions.

 

Additional classification:

choices.text: A case of superfetation
One infant is atavistic
A case of superfecundation
One infant is suppositious

questions.text: A married woman gives birth to twins. The husband doubts he is the father and gets a paternity test done. The test shows that he is the father of one infant but not the other. This is? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A case of superfecundation

 

Explanation:

 

Superfecundation:

 

  • This refers to the fertilization of two ova in the same menstrual cycle by sperm from different acts of intercourse, potentially involving different partners.
  • This scenario explains how twins can have different fathers, as one ovum could be fertilized by sperm from the husband, and the other by sperm from another man.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superfetation: This refers to fertilization of two ova from different menstrual cycles. It is an extremely rare phenomenon and has never been documented in humans, though it is known to occur in some animals.

 

Option B. One infant is atavistic: Atavism refers to the appearance of characteristics found in distant ancestors but not observed in recent generations. It does not apply to paternity.

 

Option D. One infant is suppositious: Suppositious refers to something that is fraudulently substituted. This term does not explain the situation of having different fathers for twins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Superfecundation is the fertilization of two ova in the same menstrual cycle by sperm from different partners, explaining how twins can have different fathers.

 

Ref: Page no 2188, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: In which of the following conditions do you see punched-out lesions of the retina? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Toxoplasmosis

 

Toxoplasmosis is a parasitic infection caused by Toxoplasma gondii that affects the central nervous system and retina in humans.

 

It can occur as 3 forms:

 

  1. Congenital: infants are typically born with inactive disease, and doctors may observe healed punched-out chorioretinal lesions in the macular region.
  2. Acquired: can also result in similar punched-out lesions, along with punctate outer retinal toxoplasmosis.
  3. Recurrent Toxoplasmosis: Patients may experience multiple episodes of retinal inflammation, leading to further accumulation of these punched-out lesions over time.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Posterior staphyloma: This refers to an outpouching or deformation of the posterior shell of the eye, often associated with severe myopia but not characterized by punched-out lesions.

 

Option B. Fundal coloboma: A congenital malformation resulting in missing pieces of tissue in structures forming the eye, such as the choroid and retina, which does not typically present as punched-out lesions.

 

Option C. Congenital rubella: While it can cause retinal changes, the signature features often include salt and pepper retinopathy rather than punched-out lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The appearance of punched-out lesions in the retina is crucial for diagnosing toxoplasmosis. This understanding can aid in distinguishing toxoplasmosis from other infectious or congenital conditions that affect the retina, guiding appropriate diagnostic and therapeutic interventions.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to a hospital with symptoms including persistent sadness, loss of interest in activities, difficulty sleeping, and poor appetite that have been ongoing for several months. After being diagnosed with major depressive disorder (MDD) by a psychiatrist, which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient? (Fmge July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fluoxetine

 

Fluoxetine, a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI), is the most appropriate initial treatment for major depressive disorder (MDD). SSRIs like fluoxetine are typically first-line treatments for MDD due to their efficacy and favourable side effect profile.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Haloperidol: An antipsychotic medication used primarily for schizophrenia and acute psychotic states, not as a first-line treatment for MDD.

 

Option C. Lithium: Commonly used as a mood stabilizer in bipolar disorder, not typically as a first-line treatment for MDD.

 

Option D. Buspirone: An anxiolytic used for generalized anxiety disorder, less effective as a primary treatment for MDD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fluoxetine, an SSRI, is the most appropriate initial treatment for major depressive disorder due to its efficacy and favorable side effect profile in improving mood, sleep, and appetite.

questions.text: A male baby, born to a non-consanguineous couple, presents with blisters on areas of friction. Their previous baby also experienced similar issues and unfortunately passed away at the age of 2 weeks. What is the probable diagnosis?(INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Epidermolysis bullosa

 

  • The male baby's current condition, characterized by blisters appearing in areas of friction, along with a similar history in a sibling, strongly suggests a diagnosis of a genetic condition called as epidermolysis bullosa congenita.
  • Epidermolysis bullosa is a mechano-bullous disease where blisters develop in response to mechanical trauma, often occurring in regions prone to friction such as the hands, feet, elbows, and knees.

 

 

Various types of Epidermolysis bullosa (EB) & Defects associated with them:

 

 

Other options:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The likely diagnosis in a neonate presenting with blistering at areas of friction, especially with a similar family history and early demise in a sibling, is Epidermolysis bullosa, a genetic condition causing extremely fragile skin leading to blister formation with minimal trauma.

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume I Chapter 71 Page no 71.4-71.16

questions.text: Heller's operation is done for: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Achalasia cardia

 

Heller's operation, also known as Heller myotomy, is a surgical procedure designed to treat achalasia. During this procedure, the surgeon makes a series of cuts into the thickened muscle of the LES to allow it to relax and improve the passage of food into the stomach. So, Heller's operation is indeed done for achalasia cardia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Carcinoma esophagus: Carcinoma of the esophagus refers to cancer that starts in the esophagus. While surgeries are often performed for esophageal cancer, Heller's operation specifically is not one of them. Instead, procedures like esophagectomy (removal of all or part of the esophagus) are performed for esophageal cancer.

 

Option C. Esophageal stricture: An esophageal stricture is a narrowing of the esophagus, which can lead to difficulty swallowing. It can result from various causes, including acid reflux or injuries to the esophagus. Esophageal dilatation (stretching of the esophagus using dilators) is commonly done for esophageal strictures.

 

Option D. Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis: Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis is a condition in infants where the muscle at the junction between the stomach and the small intestine (the pylorus) becomes enlarged, leading to obstruction. The treatment for this condition is a surgery called pyloromyotomy, where the thickened muscle is split to relieve the obstruction.

 

In conclusion, among the given options, Heller's operation is specifically done for achalasia cardia (Option A).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Heller's myotomy is a surgical procedure used to treat achalasia cardia by cutting the lower esophageal sphincter muscle to relieve obstruction and improve swallowing.

questions.text: As per the Factories Act of 1948, what is the maximum permissible weekly working hours, inclusive of overtime? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) 60 hours

 

The Factories Act of 1948 permits a maximum of 48 hours of regular work per week, which can be extended up to 60 hours per week with standard overtime.

 

Factories Act – established in 1948:

 

  • Established to include all the factories except Defence, Mining, Railways and Eateries.
  • Per capita space: more than 500/ft3
  • One Safety officer for more than 1000 workers.
  • Children between 14-18 years can be employed only in certain industries and work only between 6 AM-7PM. They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours per day.
  • The maximum working hours for adults should be less than 48 hours per week or less than 9 hours per day.
  • With overtime being included, it should not be more than 60 hours per week.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Maximum work hours per week is 48 hours. With overtime one can extend it upto 60 hours.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old female patient came to the outpatient department with complaints of neck swelling. She gives a history of weight loss and palpitations. On examination, she has exophthalmos and a diffusely enlarged thyroid gland. What are the essential investigations that should be done for the patient? (INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Thyroid scan
  2. Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC)
  3. Thyroid function tests
  4. Ultrasound of neck
  5. Anti-thyroid antibody
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 3, 4, and 5 only

 

The clinical presentation of neck swelling, weight loss, palpitations, exophthalmos, and a diffusely enlarged thyroid gland suggests hyperthyroidism, likely Graves' disease.

 

FNAC is not recommended in this case because it does not provide additional diagnostic yield for Graves' disease, does not alter the treatment plan, and carries a risk of complications due to the gland's increased vascularity in Graves' disease.

 

Other Options:

 

The following investigations are essential:

 

1. Thyroid scan: A radioactive iodine uptake scan helps differentiate between diffuse uptake (indicative of Graves' disease) and nodular uptake (indicative of toxic multinodular goiter or Plummer's disease).

 

3. Thyroid function tests: These are crucial as they provide information on the levels of thyroid hormones (T3, T4) and thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH), helping confirm the diagnosis of hyperthyroidism.

 

4. Ultrasound of neck: This imaging modality helps assess the thyroid gland's structure and can reveal increased vascularity, which is characteristic of Graves' disease.

 

5. Anti-thyroid antibody: Testing for antibodies, such as TSH receptor antibodies (TRAbs) or thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulins (TSI), is important for diagnosing autoimmune thyroid diseases like Graves' disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient with clinical signs of hyperthyroidism and a diffusely enlarged thyroid gland, essential investigations include a thyroid scan, thyroid function tests, ultrasound of the neck, and anti-thyroid antibody tests. Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) is not typically required in these cases.

questions.text:
Which of the following investigations is used to diagnose unicornuate uterus?  (INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Falloposcopy
  2. Laparoscopy
  3. HSG
  4. X-ray
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 2, 3

 

Explanation:

 

2. Laparoscopy: This is a minimally invasive surgical procedure that allows direct visualization of the pelvic organs, including the uterus. It is effective in diagnosing structural anomalies like a unicornuate uterus.

 

3. HSG (Hysterosalpingogram): This is an X-ray procedure where a contrast dye is injected into the uterine cavity and fallopian tubes. It helps in visualizing the shape of the uterine cavity and the patency of the fallopian tubes, making it useful in diagnosing a unicornuate uterus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 2, 4: While laparoscopy (2) is correct, X-ray (4) alone is not specific or detailed enough to diagnose a unicornuate uterus.

 

Option B. 1, 2: Falloposcopy (1) is used to visualize the interior of the fallopian tubes, not to diagnose uterine anomalies. Laparoscopy (2) is correct but falloposcopy is not appropriate for this diagnosis.

 

Option C. 1, 3: Similar to option B, falloposcopy (1) is not relevant for diagnosing uterine anomalies, even though HSG (3) is correct.

 

  • Falloposcopy: Refers to the visualization of the interior of the fallopian tube lumen and tubal ostia using a flexible fiber optic device via hysteroscope.
  • Diagnosis of Mullerian Anomalies: Can be achieved through various methods, including:
    1. Ultrasound (Preferably 3D USG)
    2. MRI (Investigation of choice)
    3. HSG
    4. Hystero-laparoscopy

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laparoscopy and HSG are effective diagnostic tools for identifying unicornuate uterus and other Mullerian anomalies.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition Pg 47, William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition pg418

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presented with hearing loss. On examination, a white pearly mass is seen behind an intact TM as shown below. There is no history of TM perforation or surgery. What will be the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Congenital cholesteatoma

 

Explanation: 

 

The presence of a white pearly mass behind an intact tympanic membrane in a young child with no history of tympanic membrane perforation or surgery strongly suggests congenital cholesteatoma. Congenital cholesteatoma occurs due to the presence of residual epithelial cells trapped within the middle ear during embryogenesis, which later proliferate. This condition is typically seen in the anterosuperior quadrant of the tympanic membrane.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Primary cholesteatoma: Primary cholesteatoma usually involves a retraction pocket and is associated with a history of eustachian tube dysfunction. It is not typically seen with an intact tympanic membrane without a history of perforation or retraction.

 

Option C. Secondary cholesteatoma: Secondary cholesteatoma arises due to chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) with tympanic membrane perforation or from a previous surgical procedure. It does not present with an intact tympanic membrane.

 

Option D. Tubotympanic CSOM: Tubotympanic chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) is associated with a central perforation of the tympanic membrane and chronic discharge. It is not consistent with an intact tympanic membrane and a white pearly mass.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Congenital cholesteatoma is characterized by a white pearly mass behind an intact tympanic membrane in the absence of any history of perforation or surgery. It is typically found in the anterosuperior quadrant of the middle ear.

questions.text: You are a nutritionist giving a lecture about milk pasteurization and its quality assurance tests. A curious student inquires about the various tests to validate the efficacy of pasteurization. You begin to list them, but highlight one that is not directly related to the pasteurization process. Which of the following tests does not directly evaluate the efficiency of milk pasteurization? [INICET NOV 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) lodine test 

 

  • Given tests are associated with the milk pasteurization process except for the iodine test.
  • This test is conducted to examine the potential adulteration of milk with starch or cereal flour.
  • Iodine test - The presence of addition of starch in milk can be detected using an iodine test.
  • When two or three drops of iodine solution is added to milk taken in a test tube, the solution turns dark blue.
  • This shows the presence of starch mixed with the milk.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phosphatase Test: Used to check for the presence of the enzyme phosphatase, which should be inactivated by proper pasteurization. This ensures that the milk has been heated sufficiently.

 

Option C. Standard Plate Count: Measures the total bacterial count to ensure it meets the standards for pasteurized milk. A lower count indicates effective pasteurization.

 

Option D. Methylene Blue Reduction Test: Measures the time it takes for methylene blue to lose its color, which correlates with bacterial activity; high counts indicate inadequate pasteurization. This test helps verify the reduction of microbial load.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PASTEURIZATION TESTS:

 

  1. Phosphatase Test: Widely used test
  2. Standard Plate Count: Standard is coliforms be absent in 1 ml of milk
  3. Methylene blue reduction test: Enforced limit is 30,000 bacterial count per ml of pasteurized milk

questions.text: In a triage setting, which of the following categories requires the highest priority intervention? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Red

 

In a triage setting, particularly in emergency and disaster scenarios, different colors are used to categorize the urgency of patients' conditions. 

 

This indicates that the patient has life-threatening injuries and requires immediate intervention to save their life. Patients in this category are to be treated first.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Yellow: This signifies that the patient has serious injuries that are not immediately life-threatening. Their treatment can be delayed briefly, but they still need urgent care.

 

Option C. Green: This color is used for patients with minor injuries who are stable enough to wait for a longer period without immediate intervention. These are the "walking wounded."

 

Option D. Black: This category is used for patients who are either deceased or have such extensive injuries that they are not expected to survive given the level of care available. In a mass casualty incident, these patients may be deemed beyond help and may not receive treatment due to limited resources.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In triage, patients categorized as 'Red' require the highest priority intervention due to the life-threatening nature of their injuries and the necessity of immediate treatment to save their lives.

choices.text: At point E, the nerve is more excitable
Point C to D is due to opening of Na+ and closure of K+ channels
Point B to D is refractory period

questions.text: True statement regarding the given nerve action potential curve is?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Point B to D is refractory period

 

Explanation:

 

The correct statement regarding the given nerve action potential curve is point B to D is the refractory period.

 

 

AT POINT 1 - Resting membrane potential: membrane is more permeable to K+ than Na+ at rest. Voltage-gated Na+ and K+ channels are closed.

 

AT POINT 2 - Membrane depolarization: Na+ activation gate opens à Na+ flows inward.

 

AT POINT 3 - Membrane repolarization: Na+ inactivation gate closes at peak potential, thus stopping Na+ inflow. K+ activation gate opens → K+ flows outward.

 

AT POINT 4 - Membrane hyperpolarization: K+ activation gates are slow to close → excess K+ efflux and brief period of hyperpolarization. Voltage-gated Na+ channels switch back to resting state. Na+/K+ pump restores ions concentration.

 

Point 2 to 4 is a part of the refractory period. During this period, the application of even a stronger stimulus will not elicit an action potential.

 

The refractory period is divided into two, an absolute refractory period and a relative refractory period. During the absolute refractory period, the nerve will not be excited no matter how strong a stimulus is given. However, during the relative refractory period, stronger than normal stimuli can cause excitation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Incorrect. Threshold potential is reached just before point B where a rapid depolarization phase begins.

 

Option B: Incorrect. At point E, the nerve is not more excitable; rather, it is in a hyperpolarized state where more than the normal stimulus would be needed to generate another action potential.

 

Option C: Incorrect. The transition from C to D is characterized by the closing of Na+ channels and the opening of K+ channels, not the other way around.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The phases of an action potential -

 

  • Point A: Represents the resting membrane potential.
  • Point B: Marks the threshold potential.

 

Point C: Represents the peak of the action potential.

 

  • Point D: Repolarization phase
  • Point E: Hyperpolarization phase
  • Absolute refractory period includes points B to around point C
  • Relative refractory period from around point C to D

questions.text: As per United Nations Sustainable Development Goals, Targets for MMR and U5MR to be achieved by 2030 are: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 70 MMR, 25 U5MR

 

The United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) were established in 2016 as a global agenda to be achieved by 2030. Among the 17 goals outlined, Goal 3 is specifically focused on health and well-being.

 

Under this goal:

 

  • Target 3.1 aims to reduce the global maternal mortality ratio (MMR) to less than 70 per 100,000 live births.
  • Target 3.2 focuses on reducing the under-5 mortality rate (U5MR) to 25 per 1,000 live births and neonatal mortality to 12 per 1,000 live births.

 

These targets are part of a broader effort to improve health outcomes and ensure universal health coverage by 2030.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The United Nations Sustainable Development Goals aim to reduce the maternal mortality ratio to below 70 per 100,000 live births and the under-5 mortality rate to 25 per 1,000 live births by 2030.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a radiological finding in a patient with left heart failure? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Focal oligemia

 

Focal oligemia, also known as the Westermark sign, is a radiological finding indicative of pulmonary embolism, not heart failure. It represents a regional reduction in lung vascularity and is seen on chest radiographs as an area of decreased blood flow and enhanced clarity due to vascular obstruction from a clot.

 

Other Options:

 

Radiological Findings in Left Heart Failure:

 

Option A. Kerley B lines: These are thin linear opacities caused by interstitial edema, especially near the lung bases, and are commonly associated with congestive heart failure.

 

Option C. Increased venous blood in lung: Also known as pulmonary venous hypertension, this finding is due to increased pressure in the pulmonary veins that results from left heart failure.

 

Option D. Change in upper lobe circulation: This refers to the redistribution of blood flow to the upper lobes, a classic sign of pulmonary venous hypertension seen in left heart failure.

 

Further Stages of Left Heart Failure on CXR:

 

  1. Stage 1 (PCWP 13-18 mmHg): Cardiomegaly, redistribution of pulmonary vessels, broad vascular pedicle.
  2. Stage 2 (PCWP 18-25 mmHg): Kerley B lines and peribronchial cuffing indicating interstitial edema.
  3. Stage 3 (PCWP > 25 mmHg): Alveolar edema leading to consolidation and pleural effusion.

 

Educational Objective:


In patients with suspected heart failure, radiological findings such as Kerley B lines, increased pulmonary venous pressure, and altered upper lobe circulation are indicative. Focal oligemia, however, suggests a differential diagnosis of pulmonary embolism and should prompt further investigation for this condition rather than heart failure.

 

 

Reference - Radiology assistant/ CXR in heart failure

questions.text: A patient is prescribed a corrective lens with the following prescription: -1D spherical, -2D cylinder at 180 degrees. What type of refractive error is being corrected? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) With the rule astigmatism

 

  • In the context of refractive errors corrected by lenses, here's an explanation of each type of astigmatism as mentioned:

 

In this condition, the eye's steepest curve is oriented vertically (up and down). This is the most common type of astigmatism. The -2D cylindrical correction at 180 degrees indicates that the correction is applied horizontally, which compensates for the steeper vertical curvature.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Against the Rule Astigmatism: Here, the steepest curvature is horizontal (side to side). Corrective lenses for this type would have cylindrical axes oriented vertically (usually at 90 degrees).

 

Option C. Simple Astigmatism: This occurs when one principal meridian is emmetropic (normal), meaning no refractive error, while the other has myopia (short-sightedness) or hyperopia (long-sightedness). There is only one refractive error to correct.

 

Option D. Mixed Astigmatism: This type features one meridian with myopia and the perpendicular meridian with hyperopia. Essentially, one axis is near sighted, and the other is farsighted, requiring complex lens corrections to address both issues simultaneously.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

When prescribed corrective lenses for astigmatism, understanding the orientation and type of astigmatism (with the rule, against the rule, simple, or mixed) is crucial for ensuring the correct lens type and orientation is used, thus maximizing visual clarity and health.

questions.text: Lactulose is ? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Galactose and fructose

 

Lactulose is a synthetic disaccharide used primarily as a laxative and in the treatment of hepatic encephalopathy. It is composed of:

 

  • Galactose: A monosaccharide commonly found in dairy products.
  • Fructose: A monosaccharide found in many plants, where it is often bonded to glucose to form the disaccharide sucrose.

 

Lactulose is different from lactose, which is a natural disaccharide found in milk and composed of galactose and glucose.

 

Comparison with Other Disaccharides:

  • Lactose: Galactose + Glucose (found in milk, with a beta bond)
  • Maltose: Glucose + Glucose (alpha 1,4 bond)
  • Isomaltose: Glucose + Glucose (alpha 1,6 bond)
  • Trehalose: Glucose + Glucose (alpha 1,1 bond)
  • Sucrose: Glucose + Fructose (table sugar, with an alpha bond)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lactulose is composed of galactose and fructose, differentiating it from lactose, which is made up of galactose and glucose. It is commonly used for its medicinal properties, particularly as a laxative.

questions.text: What is the prevalence of a disease with an incidence of a disease of 4 cases per 1000 individuals in the population and an average duration of 2 years? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) 8/1000

 

Prevalence represents the total number of cases of a disease in a population at a given time. It can be calculated using the relationship between incidence (the rate of new cases) and the average duration of the disease.

 

Given that the incidence of the disease is 4 per 1000 of the population, and the average duration of the disease is 2 years, we can calculate the prevalence as follows:

 

Prevalence = 4/1000 x 2 = 8/1000 or 0.8%

 

Educational Objective:

 

The prevalence can be calculated using the formula:

 

Prevalence = Incidence x Duration.

questions.text: Which of the following ions is involved in peripheral oxygen sensing chemoreceptors?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Potassium

 

Explanation

 

Potassium is involved in peripheral oxygen sensing chemoreceptors.

 

Chemoreceptors are made up of two types of cells, type I or glomus cells and type II or sustentacular cells. Glomus cells have afferent nerve endings, which are stimulated by hypoxia. Type II cells are glial cells and provide support for type I cells.

 

Type I glomus cells (carotid and aortic body) have O2-sensitive K+ channels. Conductance of these channels is reduced proportionally to the degree of hypoxia resulting in K+ efflux → depolarization of cell and causes Ca+ influx →Excitation of afferent nerve ending.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Calcium: Calcium is also involved but primarily in response to the depolarization initiated by changes in potassium ion conductance. It is not the initial ion involved in oxygen sensing.

 

Option C. Sodium: Sodium ions are not directly involved in the oxygen-sensing mechanism of peripheral chemoreceptors.

 

Option D. Chlorine: Chlorine ions are not involved in the oxygen-sensing functions of peripheral chemoreceptors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Potassium ions are crucial for the function of peripheral oxygen-sensing chemoreceptors, where they regulate the membrane potential and responsiveness of the cells to hypoxia. This process is vital for the body's ability to detect and respond to low oxygen levels, ensuring adequate oxygenation and cellular function.

questions.text: Identify the histopathological image.  (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Basal cell carcinoma

 

Explanation:

 

The histopathological image shows a characteristic palisading arrangement of hyperchromatic (darkly stained) cells, which is indicative of basal cell carcinoma (BCC).

 

Basal cell carcinoma is a type of skin cancer that arises from the basal cells of the epidermis. It is characterized by the presence of basaloid cells arranged in a palisading pattern, with peripheral cells exhibiting hyperchromatic nuclei and a paler center.

 

The key features that suggest this image represents basal cell carcinoma include:

 

  1. Palisading arrangement: The tumor cells are arranged in a distinct palisading pattern, with peripheral cells arranged in a radial fashion around the center.
  2. Hyperchromatic cells: The cells at the periphery of the tumor nests have darkly stained (hyperchromatic) nuclei, which is a characteristic feature of basal cell carcinoma.
  3. Lack of keratinization: Unlike squamous cell carcinoma, there is no evidence of keratinization (formation of keratin pearls) in this image.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Squamous cell carcinoma: This type of skin cancer typically shows evidence of keratinization and does not exhibit the distinctive palisading pattern observed in the image.

 

Option C. Adenocarcinoma: This is a type of cancer that originates from glandular epithelial cells and is not typically found in the skin.

 

Option D. Malignant melanoma: This is a type of skin cancer that arises from melanocytes and typically exhibits a different morphological appearance, with the presence of melanin pigment and atypical melanocytes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The characteristic palisading arrangement of hyperchromatic basaloid cells is a hallmark feature of basal cell carcinoma, a type of skin cancer that arises from the basal cells of the epidermis.

questions.text: An infant present with hypotonia and seizures. It was confirmed to be cerebrohepatorenal syndrome. Which of the following is accumulated in the brain in cerebrohepatorenal syndrome?  (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Long chain fatty acid

 

Long-chain fatty acids are the substances that accumulate in the brain of individuals with cerebrohepatorenal syndrome, contributing to the neurological symptoms such as hypotonia and seizures. This accumulation disrupts normal brain function and leads to the characteristic clinical features of the syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glucose: Glucose is a normal energy source for the brain and is not typically accumulated in the brain in this syndrome.

 

Option C. Lactic acid: While lactic acid can accumulate in some metabolic disorders, it is not the primary substance that accumulates in cerebrohepatorenal syndrome.

 

Option D. Triglycerides: Triglycerides are a form of fat storage and are not typically accumulated in the brain in this syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zellweger syndrome or Cerebrohepatorenal syndrome is due to defective oxidation of very long chain fatty acids (VLCFA). Peroxisomal enzymes are produced; but their entry into peroxisome is denied. This leads to insufficient oxidation of VLCFA. Accumulation of VLCFA in CNS causes profound neurologic impairment and death in childhood.

questions.text: A person was brought to the emergency department with facial swelling, itching, and hypotension following a bee sting. The mentioned clinical features are due to the increase in which immunoglobulin? (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IgE

 

The given clinical features suggest a anaphylactic reaction, a type 1 hypersensitivity reaction, and is mediated by immunoglobulin E.

 

Immediate (Type I) hypersensitivity reactions refer to allergic reactions or allergies.

 

It is a rapid immunologic reaction that is triggered by the binding of an antigen to IgE antibody on the surface of mast cells. It occurs in a previously sensitized individual. These reactions are induced by environmental antigens (allergens) that stimulate strong TH2 responses and IgE production in genetically susceptible individuals.

 

Systemic anaphylaxis is characterized by vascular shock, widespread edema, and difficulty in breathing. It may occur in sensitized individuals in hospital settings after administration of foreign proteins (e.g., antisera), hormones, enzymes, polysaccharides, and drugs (such as the antibiotic penicillin), or in the community setting following exposure to food allergens (e.g. peanuts, shellfish) or insect toxins (e.g. those in bee venom).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IgA: IgA is mainly involved in mucosal immunity and does not play a primary role in type I hypersensitivity or anaphylactic reactions.

 

Option C. IgM: IgM is the first antibody produced during an initial immune response but is not involved in allergic or type I hypersensitivity reactions.

 

Option D. IgG: IgG is involved in various immune responses, including type II and type III hypersensitivity reactions, but not in the immediate hypersensitivity reaction that leads to anaphylaxis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

IgE is the immunoglobulin responsible for mediating type I hypersensitivity reactions, such as anaphylaxis, which can occur in response to bee stings or other allergens.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 373

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presented to the psychiatry OPD and tells that aliens have been speaking to him and telling him to kill his cousins. This has been going on for 7 months. What is the most likely diagnosis?(FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Schizophrenia

 

Patient is having auditory hallucinations for 7 months which points to a diagnosis of Schizophrenia.

 

According to DSM-5, for the diagnosis of schizophrenia, the total duration of illness should be at least six months.

 

Out of these six months, for at least one month, the patient should have two or more of the following symptoms. At least one of these two symptoms should be (1), (2) or (3):

 

  1. Delusions
  2. Hallucinations
  3. Disorganised speech (which is a result of formal thought disorders)
  4. Disorganised behaviour or catatonic behaviour (symptoms)
  5. Negative symptoms (i.e., diminished emotional expression or avolition)

 

The ICD-11 also uses similar symptom criteria for the diagnosis of schizophrenia; however, the duration criterion of ICD-11 is one month and not six months.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Delusional disorder: In Delusional disorder, hallucinations are usually absent. If hallucinations are present, they have the same content as the delusion.

 

Option C. Brief psychotic disorder: If the symptoms would have been for < 1 month, then Brief psychotic disorder would be the diagnosis.

 

Option D. Mania: Mania has following symptoms:

 

  • M - Mood elevation (undue excessive happiness) or irritable mood
  • A - Activity levels increased
  • F - Flight of ideas
  • A - Abnormally increased levels of activity/energy
  • S - Sleep decreased (decreased need for sleep) (e.g. patient feels refreshed after 2 hours of sleep)
  • T - Talkativeness (overtalkativeness)
  • G - Grandiose ideas and increased self-esteem (increased self-confidence, maybe boastful, and may make big claims.
  • D – Distractibility
  • P - Painful consequences (involvement in activities with potentially painful consequences like making foolish investments)

choices.text: Cigarette smoking is a risk factor
Carcinoma of body of pancreas often present with jaundice

questions.text: All of these are characteristic features of pancreatic carcinoma except: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Carcinoma of body of pancreas often present with jaundice

 

Patients with carcinoma of the head of the pancreas, not the body develop jaundice. This is due to obstruction of the biliary tract.

 

Etiology of pancreatic carcinoma

 

  1. Heavy cigarette smokers have higher incidence than the non-smokers.
  2. Diet with high total caloric value and high consumption of animal proteins and fats is related to higher incidence of pancreatic cancer. Obesity is a risk factor for pancreatic cancer.
  3. Chemical carcinogens: Individuals exposed to β-naphthylamine, benzidine and nitrosamines have higher incidence of cancer of the pancreas.
  4. Diabetes mellitus: Patients of long-standing diabetes mellitus have a higher incidence.
  5. Chronic pancreatitis patients are at increased risk.
  6. H. pylori infection has been reported to have association with pancreatic cancer.
  7. Genetic factors have been found to have association with pancreatic cancer e.g. its occurrence in first-degree relatives in 10% cases, occurrence in certain hereditary syndromes (Lynch, FPC, HNPCC).

 

Obstructive jaundice is more often and early in the course of disease in cases with carcinoma head of the pancreas (80%), and less often in cancer of the body and tail of the pancreas (as they do not impinge on the biliary duct)

 

Two features are characteristic of pancreatic cancer:

 

  • Highly invasive (even “early” invasive pancreatic cancers extensively invade peripancreatic tissues)
  • Elicits an intense non-neoplastic host reaction composed of fibroblasts, lymphocytes, and extracellular matrix (called a “desmoplastic response”).

 

Dense stromal fibrosis accompanies the invasive cancer, and there is a proclivity for perineural invasion within and beyond the organ. Lymphatic and large vessel invasion are also commonly seen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cigarette smoking is a risk factor: Directly linked to higher incidence rates of pancreatic carcinoma.

 

Option C. They elicit an intense desmoplastic response: Refers to the fibroblastic proliferation in the stroma surrounding the tumor, a hallmark of pancreatic cancer.

 

Option D. Perineural invasion is common: Indicates the aggressive nature of pancreatic cancer, with frequent invasion of nerves by cancer cells, contributing to pain and complex management challenges.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While pancreatic carcinomas are generally associated with intense desmoplastic responses and perineural invasion, jaundice is specifically linked more with carcinoma at the head of the pancreas rather than the body or tail.

questions.text: A person often feels that his hands are contaminated and he is forced to wash his hands. Recently, he feels this repetitive, distressing thought of repetitive hand washing has begun affecting his performance. Which of the following is the best treatment option for this patient? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Exposure and response prevention

 

The patient's symptoms are consistent with Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD). One of the most effective treatments for OCD is Exposure and Response Prevention (ERP), which is a type of Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) specific for OCD.

 

Exposure and response prevention is the mainstay treatment for OCD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. DBT (Dialectical Behavior Therapy): DBT is primarily used for borderline personality disorder and other self-harming behaviors.

 

Option C. Systematic desensitization: Systematic desensitization is a behavioral technique mainly used to treat phobias by gradually exposing the patient to the phobic stimulus.

 

Option D. CBT (Cognitive Behavioral Therapy): CBT is a broader therapeutic technique and is used in a variety of psychiatric disorders.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

For OCD, Exposure and Response Prevention (ERP), a specialized form of CBT, is the evidence-based first-line treatment. It involves exposing patients to their obsessional triggers while refraining from performing their compulsive rituals, gradually reducing the distress elicited by obsessions.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 425.

questions.text: A patient presents with neck swelling and difficulty in swallowing food. Histopathological examination of the swelling shows increased nests of cells with amyloid deposition. Which of the following is the cell of origin of this mass?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Parafollicular cells

 

Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC) is the type of thyroid cancer associated with increased nests of cells and amyloid deposition. MTC arises from the parafollicular cells (also known as C cells) of the thyroid. These cells produce calcitonin, a hormone involved in calcium homeostasis. The presence of amyloid in MTC is due to the deposition of calcitonin, which can be detected as amyloid material in histopathological examinations. This type of thyroid cancer is distinct from other forms such as papillary, follicular, or anaplastic thyroid carcinomas, which originate from follicular cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endothelial cells: Incorrect. Endothelial cells line blood vessels and are not associated with thyroid tumors that show amyloid deposition.

 

Option C. Follicular cells: Incorrect. Follicular cells give rise to papillary, follicular, and anaplastic thyroid cancers, not medullary thyroid carcinoma.

 

Option D. Hurthle cells: Incorrect. Hurthle cells are a variant of follicular cells and can be seen in Hurthle cell carcinoma, another type of thyroid cancer, but not in medullary thyroid carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Medullary thyroid carcinoma, characterized by nests of cells and amyloid deposition, arises from the parafollicular cells (C cells) of the thyroid.

choices.text: Rosette cataract with control of blood sugar level
Immature cataract with Phacoemulsification + IOL implantation

questions.text: A 60-year-old female patient complaints of blurring of vision and gives history of Diabetes for the past 10 years. On examination findings as shown in image were seen. What is the most likely diagnosis and treatment for the same. (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Immature cataract with Phacoemulsification + IOL implantation

 

Immature cataract refers to a cataract that has not yet progressed to cause complete opacity and loss of vision. Phacoemulsification is a modern cataract surgery technique that uses ultrasonic vibrations to emulsify the lens, allowing for its removal and replacement with an IOL. This is a common treatment for cataracts that are significantly affecting vision.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sunflower Cataract with Lens Extraction: Sunflower cataract is characterized by the presence of a central, sunflower-like opacity on the lens. It is commonly associated with conditions such as Wilson's disease, where copper deposits on the lens. Treatment typically involves surgical removal of the cataractous lens (lens extraction), often followed by the implantation of an artificial intraocular lens (IOL).

 

Option B. Rosette Cataract with Control of Blood Sugar Level: A rosette cataract usually forms a star-shaped pattern and is often associated with trauma. While controlling blood sugar levels is essential for patients with diabetes to prevent the progression of diabetic retinopathy and other complications, it may not reverse the changes already present in the lens.

 

Option D. Zonular Cataract with Lensectomy: Zonular cataract refers to the opacities that affect the zone or region of the lens. A lensectomy involves the surgical removal of the lens, which can be applied to different types of cataracts, often followed by the placement of an IOL.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The diagnosis of cataracts involves a thorough examination of the lens using slit-lamp microscopy or similar diagnostic tools. Understanding the underlying causes, such as diabetes, and recognizing the specific patterns associated with different types of cataracts are crucial for determining the appropriate treatment, which often involves surgery to restore vision. Regular monitoring and management of blood sugar levels are essential in diabetic patients to prevent or slow the progression of diabetic cataracts.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with daytime sleepiness, impaired concentration, and impaired memory. On exam, her BMI is 43, BP is 170/100 mm Hg. Her daytime ABG analysis shows HCO3 - 33 mEq/L, PaCO2 - 53 mmHg, and PaO2 - 70 mmHg. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Obesity hypoventilation syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

The patient has obesity hypoventilation syndrome (OHS), which is characterized by the following criteria:

 

  • A BMI of 30 or more, indicating obesity.
  • Hypercarbia or hypercapnia, defined as PaCO2 > 45 mm Hg.
  • The awake ABG must be taken (daytime ABG).
  • No other causes (central or peripheral neuromuscular) should be present to explain the hypercapnia.

 

The patient's symptoms and test results align with OHS. OHS patients typically present with symptoms like daytime sleepiness, impaired concentration, and impaired memory, which are noted in this patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Obstructive sleep apnea: This condition typically causes issues during sleep, not in the daytime. It is characterized by repeated episodes of partial or complete upper airway obstruction during sleep.

 

Option B. Narcolepsy: This is a sleep disorder characterized by excessive daytime sleepiness and sudden sleep attacks, but it does not align with the patient’s clinical picture, which includes specific ABG results and severe obesity.

 

Option D. Central sleep apnea: Like obstructive sleep apnea, central sleep apnea occurs during sleep and involves periods of non-breathing. It does not match the daytime ABG findings of this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Obesity hypoventilation syndrome is diagnosed based on a BMI of 30 or more, daytime hypercapnia (PaCO2 > 45 mm Hg), and the absence of other causes for hypercapnia.

questions.text: Which of these classifications of bile duct injury takes into account the location of injury, and thermal and vascular injury to bile ducts? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hannover 

 

  • When discussing bile duct injuries, several classification systems have been developed to categorize these injuries based on their nature, location, and the extent of damage. 

 

This system categorizes bile duct injuries based on the anatomical structure involved and the extent of the injury, including vascular injuries.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bismuth Classification: Primarily focuses on the location of the bile duct injury in relation to the confluence of the right and left hepatic ducts. This classification is widely used to describe bile duct injuries post-cholecystectomy.

 

Option B. Strassberg Classification (also known as the Strassberg-Bismuth classification): This is an extension of the Bismuth classification, adding more detail and incorporating the critical view of safety concept. It includes acute injuries, but it is based on location alone. Associated vascular injuries are not included.

 

Option C. Stewart-Way Classification: This classification focuses on the phase of the operation in which the injury occurs and the type of injury, including thermal damage. It categorizes injuries into four types:

 

  1. Type I: Cystic duct leak or leakage from a small peripheral hepatic radicle close to the gallbladder fossa.
  2. Type II: Injury to the main bile duct that does not involve excision, typically a lateral injury.
  3. Type III: Complete transaction or excision of a segment of the main bile duct.
  4. Type IV: Injury involving damage to the hepatic duct confluence and bifurcation.

 

Stewart-Way classification does not account for associated vascular injury.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bismuth and Strassberg classifications are anatomically based classifications of bile duct injury.

questions.text: Identify the most common site of an intra-abdominal abscess:(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Subhepatic space

 

  1. The right subhepatic space is a deep space located in Rutherford Morison's pouch between the liver, transverse colon, and hepatic flexure. It is a common site of intra-abdominal abscess (second to pelvis).
  2. Abscesses in the right subhepatic space may occur due to conditions such as appendicitis, cholecystitis, perforated duodenal ulcer, or as a complication of upper abdominal surgery.
    • Also known as Rutherford Morison's pouch, the subhepatic space is situated between the liver's posterior surface and the right kidney's anterior surface.
    • It's a potential space that can collect fluid or pus.
    • It is a common site for abscess formation, especially after conditions like appendicitis, where the infection can spread upwards into this space.
    • Due to its anatomical location and the potential for infections like appendicitis to spread to this region, the subhepatic space is recognized as the most common site for intra-abdominal abscesses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Peri splenic space: The peri-splenic space is located around the spleen and is bounded by the diaphragm, stomach, and the splenic flexure of the colon. Abscesses in this space can arise from a splenic infection or trauma, but it is not the most common site for intra-abdominal abscesses.

 

Option B. Left subphrenic space: The left subphrenic space is located between the diaphragm and the spleen/stomach. It's a potential space for abscess formation, especially after splenic surgeries or gastric surgeries. However, it's not the most common site for intra-abdominal abscesses compared to the right side.

 

Option C. Right subphrenic space: The right subphrenic space is located between the diaphragm and the liver. Abscesses in this space can arise due to infections that spread from the liver or gallbladder, or after surgeries involving these organs. It is one of the potential sites for abscess formation, but not the most common.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The most common site of an intra-abdominal abscess is subhepatic space.

questions.text: Uracil was found in genetic code. Which vitamin deficiency leads to this condition:(INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Folate

 

  • Folate deficiency is the correct answer. Folate (also known as vitamin B9) plays a crucial role in DNA synthesis and repair. When there is a deficiency in folate, it can lead to the misincorporation of Uracil into DNA, causing DNA instability and other genetic abnormalities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. B12: A deficiency in vitamin B12 is not directly associated with the presence of Uracil in the genetic code. Vitamin B12 deficiency primarily affects red blood cell production and neurological functions.

 

Option B. B6: A deficiency in vitamin B6 is also not directly related to the presence of Uracil in the genetic code. Vitamin B6 deficiency can lead to various neurological symptoms but does not cause Uracil incorporation into DNA.

 

Option D. Vit E: Vitamin E deficiency does not lead to the presence of Uracil in the genetic code. Vitamin E is primarily known for its antioxidant properties and its role in maintaining cell membranes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Genetic code is related to DNA, but DNA do not contain Uracil. In pyrimidine synthesis, UMP is the first pyrimidine nucleotide to be synthesized and other two pyrimidines thymine and Cytosine are synthesized from it. Uracil to cytosine conversion requires amino group addition provided by glutamine. Uracil is converted to thymine by enzyme thymidylate synthase by methylation where methyl group is donated by methyl-THF. So, a deficiency Folate will result in thymine deficiency and may lead to uracil appearing in the DNA in place of thymine.

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 333

questions.text: A newborn baby came with complaints of hepatitis and cataract, lethargy & hypotonia. Which enzyme deficiency is most likely to be responsible for this condition? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Galactose 1 phosphate uridyl transferase

 

The newborn presents with symptoms of hepatitis, cataract, lethargy, and hypotonia, which are indicative of a metabolic disorder involving galactose metabolism. The condition described here is galactosemia, specifically due to a deficiency in the enzyme Galactose 1 phosphate uridyl transferase (GALT).

 

Galactosemia is characterized by the inability to convert galactose into glucose. This metabolic block leads to the accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate in various tissues, causing damage. The primary symptoms include:

 

  • Hepatitis: Liver damage due to the accumulation of toxic substances.
  • Cataract: Formation of oil drop cataracts in the lens of the eye due to galactose accumulation.
  • Lethargy and Hypotonia: Due to the overall metabolic derangement and hypoglycemia.

 

Metabolic pathway Galactose:

 

 

The key enzymes involved include Galactokinase and Galactose 1 phosphate uridyl transferase. In classical galactosemia, the deficiency of the GALT enzyme leads to the clinical manifestations described.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Galactokinase: Galactokinase deficiency leads to a milder form of galactosemia, primarily causing cataracts but not the full spectrum of symptoms like hepatitis and hypotonia seen in this case.

 

Option C. Uridyl glucuronyl transferase: This enzyme is related to bilirubin metabolism and is implicated in neonatal jaundice, not in the metabolism of galactose. Hence, its deficiency does not match the symptoms described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Galactosemia due to Galactose 1 phosphate uridyl transferase deficiency presents with hepatitis, cataracts, lethargy, and hypotonia, and is a contraindication for breastfeeding.

choices.text: Aspirin increases fever by inhibiting prostaglandin synthesis
PGI2 is responsible for resetting the temperature to a higher level
Fever occurs during inflammation due to release of histamine

questions.text: Which of the following is true about fever? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) IL-1 is an endogenous pyrogen

 

Fever is a common symptom of many illnesses, and it is an important defense mechanism of the body. It is often associated with infection, inflammation, and tissue damage. Pyrogens are substances that cause fever.

 

IL-1 (interleukin-1) is an endogenous pyrogen, meaning that it is a substance produced by the body that induces fever. It is produced by activated immune cells such as macrophages and monocytes in response to infection, inflammation, and tissue damage. IL-1 acts on the hypothalamus to increase the set point of the thermostat, leading to a higher body temperature.

 

  • Endogenous pyrogens, such as prostaglandins, IL-1, and TNF
  • Exogenous pyrogens, which are bacterial lipopolysaccharides. They cause endogenous pyrogens to be released from leukocytes (IL-1 and TNF)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aspirin and other nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs): Aspirin and other nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) actually reduce fever by inhibiting the synthesis of prostaglandins, which are involved in the process of fever. Prostaglandins are produced by cells in the hypothalamus in response to pyrogens (fever-inducing substances), and they increase the set point of the hypothalamic thermostat, leading to a higher body temperature. NSAIDs inhibit the enzyme cyclooxygenase (COX), which is required for the synthesis of prostaglandins, thereby reducing fever.

 

Option B. PGI2 (prostaglandin I2): PGI2 (prostaglandin I2) is not responsible for resetting the temperature to a higher level.

 

Option D. Histamine: Histamine is not directly involved in the process of fever, although it is involved in the process of inflammation. Histamine is a chemical mediator that is released by mast cells and other immune cells in response to injury or infection, and it causes dilation of blood vessels and increased permeability of capillaries. This leads to the characteristic redness, swelling, and heat that are associated with inflammation. However, histamine does not directly cause fever.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: 35-year-old male presented with a swelling in the scrotum for which surgical removal was done as shown. Which of the following has the best prognosis in this patient? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Seminoma

 

Seminoma is a type of testicular cancer that typically occurs in young and middle-aged men. It is known for its excellent prognosis, primarily because it is highly sensitive to radiotherapy and chemotherapy. Seminomas usually metastasize to the lymph nodes rather than spreading hematogenously, which makes them more manageable and treatable. The overall survival rate for patients with seminoma is very high due to these factors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Teratoma: Teratomas are testicular tumors that can contain several types of tissues and may have variable behavior. While some teratomas can be benign, others can be malignant and more challenging to treat than seminomas.

 

Option C. Yolk sac tumor: Also known as endodermal sinus tumor, this is a malignant germ cell tumor more commonly seen in children. In adults, yolk sac tumors tend to have a poorer prognosis compared to seminomas.

 

Option D. Leydig cell Tumor: These tumors arise from the Leydig cells in the testes. While many Leydig cell tumors are benign, the malignant ones can be more aggressive and harder to treat than seminomas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Seminomas have the best prognosis among testicular tumors due to their high sensitivity to radiotherapy and chemotherapy and their typically limited pattern of spread to lymph nodes.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male with Marfanoid habitus presents with sharp chest pain and sudden onset dyspnea. Chest X-ray was performed and is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C Pneumothorax

 

Explanation:

 

The given CXR shows the presence of pneumothorax, which represents air in the pleural space. 

 

DIAGNOSIS: Right pneumothorax

 

MEDIASTINAL SHIFT: Contralateral

 

MOST SENSITIVE IX: CT scan

 

MOST SENSITIVE X-RAY: Expiratory X ray

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pulmonary embolism: Often presents with sudden onset dyspnea and may show signs of right heart strain on imaging, but it does not directly cause the visible signs of air in the pleural cavity as seen in pneumothorax.

 

Option B. Hydropneumothorax: This would be indicated by both air and fluid levels within the pleural space, which are not visible in this X-ray.

 

Option D. Aortic dissection: Would potentially show mediastinal widening or other structural abnormalities, which are not depicted in this image.

 

Educational Objective:


Pneumothorax is identified by the visible presence of air in the pleural space, leading to lung collapse, and is commonly associated with sudden onset chest pain and dyspnea, especially in patients with connective tissue disorders like Marfan syndrome.

questions.text: What is the usual CD4 count at which Kaposi's sarcoma is present? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) < 200

 

Kaposi's sarcoma is a cancer that commonly occurs in patients with HIV/AIDS. It is associated with human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8) infection and tends to present at lower CD4 counts as the immune system becomes increasingly compromised.

 

While Kaposi's sarcoma can technically present at any CD4 count, it is most frequently observed when the CD4 count falls below 200 cells/mm³. Studies have shown that the incidence of Kaposi's sarcoma is significantly higher in patients with CD4 counts below 200 cells/mm³, making this the most common scenario for its presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kaposi's sarcoma is most commonly observed in HIV/AIDS patients with CD4 counts below 200 cells/mm³, although it can present at any CD4 count.

questions.text: A physician is consulting with a mother who has brought her one-year-old child to a health clinic. The mother mentions that the child received the initial DPT vaccine dose at 6 weeks but has not received any subsequent vaccinations. What would be the most appropriate next step in this child's immunization schedule? [INICET MAY 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Give second dose of DPT

 

  • If there is delayed immunization in DPT doses, there is no need to repeat the schedule from the start, just continue the schedule. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Age Limits for Delayed Immunization in NIS, India

questions.text: What is the "ANMOL" Program for auxiliary nurse midwives?(FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tablet-based software

 

Explanation:

 

"ANMOL" is an abbreviation that stands for "ANM (Auxiliary Nurse Midwife) ONline." It is a tablet-based software or online monitoring tool (for RCH portal) that is specifically designed for use by auxiliary nurse midwives (ANMs).

 

The ANMOL program allows ANMs to register and track high-risk pregnancies, monitor children with low birth weight, and manage data related to their work at the sub-center level. It serves as a comprehensive monitoring and data management tool for ANMs, enabling them to efficiently carry out their responsibilities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "ANMOL" program is a tablet-based software or online monitoring tool specifically designed for auxiliary nurse midwives (ANMs) to register and track high-risk pregnancies, monitor children with low birth weight, and manage data at the sub-center level.

questions.text: A child with a sore throat/upper respiratory tract infection (URTI) started developing skin lesions after treatment with Amoxiclav as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Guttate psoriasis

 

Guttate psoriasis is commonly triggered by a preceding streptococcal infection, such as a sore throat or URTI. The hallmark of guttate psoriasis is the sudden onset of small, droplet-shaped, erythematous papules, which are scattered predominantly over the trunk, although they can also appear on the limbs. The description of the skin lesions as "raindrop-like" in appearance over the trunk, coupled with the history of a sore throat, strongly suggests guttate psoriasis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pustular psoriasis: This type of psoriasis is characterized by the presence of sterile pustules on an erythematous background. It can be triggered by the abrupt withdrawal of systemic steroids. The condition typically presents with widespread pustules rather than small papules, making it less likely in this case.

 

 

Option C. Erythrodermic psoriasis: Erythrodermic psoriasis involves more than 90% of the body surface area and is characterized by widespread erythema and scaling. It is a severe and potentially life-threatening form of psoriasis that does not match the presentation of small, discrete papules seen in this patient.

 

 

Option D. Inverse psoriasis: Inverse psoriasis presents in skin folds such as the axilla, groin, under the breasts, and other flexural areas. The lesions are usually erythematous and lack the scaling typically seen in other forms of psoriasis. The distribution and type of lesions described here do not correspond to inverse psoriasis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Guttate psoriasis is often precipitated by a streptococcal throat infection and presents with multiple, small, droplet-like erythematous papules primarily over the trunk.
